content.question: Ball <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of mass <math alttext="1.0 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and ball <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of mass <math alttext="0.5 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> travel toward each other on a horizontal surface. Both balls travel with a constant speed of <math alttext="5 meters per second " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>m/</mtext><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> until they collide. During the collision, ball <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> exerts an average force with a magnitude of <math alttext="40 newtons " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="one sixth second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac><mtext> s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on ball <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following best predicts ball <math alttext="plural Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Y</mi><mo>′</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> momentum after the collision?

choices.label: Ball <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will travel at a speed less than <math alttext="5 meters per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the same direction of travel as before the collision.

Ball <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will travel at a speed less than <math alttext="5 meters per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the opposite direction of travel as before the collision.

Ball <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will travel at a speed greater than <math alttext="5 meters per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the opposite direction of travel as before the collision.
Ball <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Y</mi><mo>′</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> motion cannot be predicted because the impulse on it is not known.

content.answer: Ball <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will travel at a speed greater than <math alttext="5 meters per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the opposite direction of travel as before the collision.

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
